content_scrubbed:
The male entitlement at RPI was through the roof. Day one of orientation, and guys are coming up to me, telling me that women get in easier. It wasn't a great welcome. They had never met me before and didn't know what I was capable of. They didn't know about my test scores, high school coursework, or that I'd written a 300 page fiction book. All they saw was that I was female.

Then there[.] the dating scene. Guys pretty much just whine about not being able to find a girlfriend and don't ask. They creep when they like a woman. You can tell when someone is creeping you because they'll start saying weird things on your Facebook and/or sending weird messages. Guys will tell you to "lower your standards" and that you owe it to the RPI guys to date because of how few women there are. Dude, I was at RPI for academics, not to date guys I wasn't attracted to.

I went to programs with liberal_arts students, and the men from other schools were so different! Friendly, confident, treated you like a person. You felt drawn to them and comfortable, instead of RPI guys who would interact with you so strangely that you cringed. RPI guys believed that you owed them a date because of your gender, not because they were someone who would make a great boyfriend.

Obviously, not all guys were like this, but way too many were.
